sn35.98:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you who is restrained and who is unrestrained.

sn35.98:1.4.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.98:1.4.eng: There are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.98:1.5.pli: Tañce bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati, veditabbametaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā:
sn35.98:1.5.eng: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them, they should understand:

sn35.98:1.7.eng: For this is what the Buddha calls decline.’

sn35.98:1.8.eng: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.98:1.9.pli: santi, bhikkhave, manoviññeyyā dhammā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.98:1.9.eng: ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.98:1.10.pli: Tañce bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati, veditabbametaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā:
sn35.98:1.10.eng: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them, they should understand:

sn35.98:1.12.eng: For this is what the Buddha calls decline.’

sn35.98:1.13.eng: This is how someone is unrestrained.

sn35.98:2.2.pli: Santi, bhikkhave, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.98:2.2.eng: There are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.98:2.3.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati, veditabbametaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā:
sn35.98:2.3.eng: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they should understand:

sn35.98:2.5.eng: For this is what the Buddha calls non-decline.’

sn35.98:2.6.eng: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.98:2.7.pli: santi, bhikkhave, manoviññeyyā dhammā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.98:2.7.eng: ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.98:2.8.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati, veditabbametaṃ bhikkhunā:
sn35.98:2.8.eng: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they should understand:

sn35.98:2.10.eng: For this is what the Buddha calls non-decline.’

sn35.98:2.11.eng: This is how someone is restrained.”

sn35.99:1.1.comm: For parallels see SN 22.5:1.4 and note. This discourse connects with the previous, which also emphasized the role of immersion in seeing the truth.

sn35.99:1.2.eng: A mendicant who has immersion truly understands.

sn35.99:1.4.eng: They truly understand that the eye is impermanent.

sn35.99:1.8.pli: ‘Yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti …pe…
sn35.99:1.8.eng: the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact is impermanent. …

sn35.99:1.9.eng: They truly understand that the mind is impermanent.

sn35.99:1.13.pli: ‘yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
sn35.99:1.13.eng: the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact is impermanent.

sn35.99:1.15.eng: A mendicant who has immersion truly understands.”

sn36.1:1.1.comm: “Feeling” (vedanā) is the affective or hedonic tone of experience. Each sense can trigger a response of pleasure, pain, or neither-pleasure-nor-pain. It is from the root vid (“know”), and is close in meaning to “experience”. For history, see note at SN 12.1:2.8.

sn36.1:1.3.pli: Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—

sn36.1:2.1.comm: The text is not explicit as to who speaks these verses. Nor, for that matter, does it say who spoke the prose; the context is elided, presumably because the editors thought it was obvious that it is the Buddha speaking. The same is true of the verses. Indeed, Iti 52 is otherwise identical to this discourse, except it indicates that the Buddha spoke both verse and prose. Whether the verses were added later is a separate matter, but clearly the text presents them as the Buddha’s words.

sn36.1:2.2.eng: a mindful disciple of the Buddha

sn36.1:3.2.eng: and the path that leads to their ending.

sn36.1:3.3.eng: With the ending of feelings, a mendicant

sn36.1:3.4.comm: By treating the feelings according to the four noble truths, the Buddha is implicitly situating all feelings as suffering.

sn36.10:1.1.pli: “Tisso imā, bhikkhave, vedanā phassajā phassamūlakā phassanidānā phassapaccayā.
sn36.10:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these three feelings are born, rooted, sourced, and dependent on contact.

sn36.10:1.3.pli: Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā.

sn36.10:1.4.pli: Sukhavedaniyaṃ, bhikkhave, phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhā vedanā.
sn36.10:1.4.eng: Pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.
sn36.10:1.4.comm: That is to say, certain kinds of contact are prone to create pleasant feelings. MN 140:19.4 treats these contacts in relation to the feelings experienced in absorptions.

sn36.10:1.5.pli: Tasseva sukhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā, yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ sukhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannā sukhā vedanā, sā nirujjhati, sā vūpasammati.
sn36.10:1.5.eng: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as pleasant, the corresponding pleasant feeling ceases and stops.

sn36.10:1.6.pli: Dukkhavedaniyaṃ, bhikkhave, phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dukkhā vedanā.
sn36.10:1.6.eng: Painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful.

sn36.10:1.7.pli: Tasseva dukkhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā, yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ dukkhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannā dukkhā vedanā, sā nirujjhati, sā vūpasammati.
sn36.10:1.7.eng: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as painful, the corresponding painful feeling ceases and stops.

sn36.10:1.8.pli: Adukkhamasukhavedaniyaṃ, bhikkhave, phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati adukkhamasukhā vedanā.
sn36.10:1.8.eng: Neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral.

sn36.10:1.9.pli: Tasseva adukkhamasukhavedaniyassa phassassa nirodhā, yaṃ tajjaṃ vedayitaṃ adukkhamasukhavedaniyaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannā adukkhamasukhā vedanā, sā nirujjhati, sā vūpasammati.
sn36.10:1.9.eng: With the cessation of that contact to be experienced as neutral, the corresponding neutral feeling ceases and stops.

sn36.10:1.10.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dvinnaṃ kaṭṭhānaṃ saṅghaṭṭanasamodhānā usmā jāyati, tejo abhinibbattati. Tesaṃyeva kaṭṭhānaṃ nānābhāvā vinikkhepā, yā tajjā usmā, sā nirujjhati, sā vūpasammati.
sn36.10:1.10.eng: When you rub two sticks together, heat is generated and fire is produced. But when you part the sticks and lay them aside, any corresponding heat ceases and stops.

sn36.10:1.11.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, imā tisso vedanā phassajā phassamūlakā phassanidānā phassapaccayā.
sn36.10:1.11.eng: In the same way, these three feelings are born, rooted, sourced, and dependent on contact.

sn36.10:1.12.pli: Tajjaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca tajjā vedanā uppajjanti.
sn36.10:1.12.eng: The appropriate feeling arises dependent on the corresponding contact.

sn36.10:1.13.pli: Tajjassa phassassa nirodhā tajjā vedanā nirujjhantī”ti.
sn36.10:1.13.eng: When the corresponding contact ceases, the appropriate feeling ceases.”

sn36.11:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn36.11:1.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn36.11:1.2.pli: “idha mayhaṃ, bhante, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi—
sn36.11:1.2.eng: “Just now, sir, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind.

sn36.11:1.3.eng: The Buddha has spoken of three feelings.

sn36.11:1.4.pli: Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—

sn36.11:1.5.eng: These are the three feelings the Buddha has spoken of.

sn36.11:1.6.eng: But the Buddha has also said:

sn36.11:1.8.pli: Kiṃ nu kho etaṃ bhagavatā sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
sn36.11:1.8.eng: What was the Buddha referring to when he said this?”

sn36.11:2.1.comm: The Buddha praises the mendicant because he had the critical acumen to notice these apparently different explanations, and, rather than assuming they were contradictory, or just ignoring the problem, he asked the Buddha for clarification. Compare the Buddha’s quite different response at SN 36.19:5.1.

sn36.11:2.2.pli: Tisso imā, bhikkhu, vedanā vuttā mayā.
sn36.11:2.2.eng: I have spoken of these three feelings.

sn36.11:2.3.pli: Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—

sn36.11:2.4.eng: These are the three feelings I have spoken of.

sn36.11:2.7.pli: Taṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhārānaṃyeva aniccataṃ sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
sn36.11:2.7.eng: When I said this I was referring to the impermanence of conditions, to the fact that conditions are

sn36.11:2.9.pli: Taṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhārānaṃyeva khayadhammataṃ …pe…

sn36.11:2.15.pli: Atha kho pana, bhikkhu, mayā anupubbasaṅkhārānaṃ nirodho akkhāto.
sn36.11:2.15.eng: But I have also explained the progressive cessation of activities.
sn36.11:2.15.comm: The “progressive cessation of activities” (anupubbasaṅkhārānaṁ nirodho), and their “settling” (vūpasama) and “tranquilizing” (passaddhi) are only mentioned here, SN 36.15, and SN 36.17. Compare the nine “progressive cessations” of AN 9.31 and DN 33:3.2.82, but these go even further to full enlightenment, as in the “progressive cessation in a definitive sense” at AN 9.61. | “Activities” (saṅkhārā) are the conditioned phenomena that are active, being both produced by and productive of other conditions. Here they are the “processes” that are stilled in the course of meditation.

sn36.11:2.16.pli: Paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa vācā niruddhā hoti.
sn36.11:2.16.eng: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has ceased.

sn36.11:2.17.pli: Dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa vitakkavicārā niruddhā honti.
sn36.11:2.17.eng: For someone who has attained the second absorption, the placing of the mind and keeping it connected have ceased.

sn36.11:2.18.pli: Tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa pīti niruddhā hoti.
sn36.11:2.18.eng: For someone who has attained the third absorption, rapture has ceased.

sn36.11:2.19.pli: Catutthaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa assāsapassāsā niruddhā honti.
sn36.11:2.19.eng: For someone who has attained the fourth absorption, breathing has ceased.

sn36.11:2.20.eng: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite space, the perception of form has ceased.

sn36.11:2.21.eng: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite consciousness, the perception of the dimension of infinite space has ceased.

sn36.11:2.22.eng: For someone who has attained the dimension of nothingness, the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness has ceased.

sn36.11:2.23.eng: For someone who has attained the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, the perception of the dimension of nothingness has ceased.

sn36.11:2.24.pli: Saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpannassa saññā ca vedanā ca niruddhā honti.
sn36.11:2.24.eng: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have ceased.

sn36.11:2.25.pli: Khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno rāgo niruddho hoti, doso niruddho hoti, moho niruddho hoti.
sn36.11:2.25.eng: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have ceased.

sn36.11:2.26.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhu, mayā anupubbasaṅkhārānaṃ vūpasamo akkhāto.
sn36.11:2.26.eng: And I have also explained the progressive settling of activities.

sn36.11:2.27.pli: Paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa vācā vūpasantā hoti.
sn36.11:2.27.eng: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has stilled.

sn36.11:2.28.pli: Dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa vitakkavicārā vūpasantā honti …pe…
sn36.11:2.28.eng: For someone who has attained the second absorption, the placing of the mind and keeping it connected have stilled. …

sn36.11:2.29.pli: saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpannassa saññā ca vedanā ca vūpasantā honti.
sn36.11:2.29.eng: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have stilled.

sn36.11:2.30.pli: Khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno rāgo vūpasanto hoti, doso vūpasanto hoti, moho vūpasanto hoti.
sn36.11:2.30.eng: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have stilled.

sn36.11:2.31.eng: There are these six levels of tranquility.
sn36.11:2.31.comm: This is the same at the corresponding point in SN 36.17:2.7, but at  SN 36.15:1.22 it speaks of the “progressive tranquilizing of activities”.

sn36.11:2.32.pli: Paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa vācā paṭippassaddhā hoti.
sn36.11:2.32.eng: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has been tranquilized.

sn36.11:2.33.pli: Dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa vitakkavicārā paṭippassaddhā honti.
sn36.11:2.33.eng: For someone who has attained the second absorption, the placing of the mind and keeping it connected have been tranquilized.

sn36.11:2.34.pli: Tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa pīti paṭippassaddhā hoti.
sn36.11:2.34.eng: For someone who has attained the third absorption, rapture has been tranquilized.

sn36.11:2.35.pli: Catutthaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa assāsapassāsā paṭippassaddhā honti.
sn36.11:2.35.eng: For someone who has attained the fourth absorption, breathing has been tranquilized.

sn36.11:2.36.pli: Saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpannassa saññā ca vedanā ca paṭippassaddhā honti.
sn36.11:2.36.eng: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have been tranquilized.

sn36.11:2.37.pli: Khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno rāgo paṭippassaddho hoti, doso paṭippassaddho hoti, moho paṭippassaddho hotī”ti.
sn36.11:2.37.eng: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have been tranquilized.”

sn36.12:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, various winds blow in the atmosphere.

sn36.12:1.2.pli: Puratthimāpi vātā vāyanti, pacchimāpi vātā vāyanti, uttarāpi vātā vāyanti, dakkhiṇāpi vātā vāyanti, sarajāpi vātā vāyanti, arajāpi vātā vāyanti, sītāpi vātā vāyanti, uṇhāpi vātā vāyanti, parittāpi vātā vāyanti, adhimattāpi vātā vāyanti.
sn36.12:1.2.eng: Winds blow from the east, the west, the north, and the south. There are winds that are dusty and dustless, cool and warm, weak and strong.

sn36.12:1.3.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, imasmiṃ kāyasmiṃ vividhā vedanā uppajjanti, sukhāpi vedanā uppajjati, dukkhāpi vedanā uppajjati, adukkhamasukhāpi vedanā uppajjatīti.
sn36.12:1.3.eng: In the same way, various feelings arise in this body: pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings.
sn36.12:1.3.comm: In Indian philosophy, the energies, breaths, or life forces (Sanskrit prāna) in the body are connected with the sensations that are experienced moving about the body. A meditator becomes acutely aware of these when sitting still for long periods.

sn36.12:2.2.eng: winds that blow in the atmosphere.

sn36.12:2.3.eng: From the east they come, also the west,

sn36.12:2.4.eng: the north, and then the south.

sn36.12:3.4.eng: these are the different gales that blow.

sn36.12:5.1.eng: But when a mendicant is keen,

sn36.12:6.2.eng: they’re without defilements in this very life.

sn36.12:6.3.eng: That knowledge master is firm in principle;

sn36.12:6.4.eng: when their body breaks up, they can’t be reckoned.”

sn36.13:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, various winds blow in the atmosphere.

sn36.13:1.2.pli: Puratthimāpi vātā vāyanti …pe… adhimattāpi vātā vāyanti.
sn36.13:1.2.eng: Winds blow from the east, the west, the north, and the south. There are winds that are dusty and dustless, cool and warm, weak and strong.

sn36.13:1.3.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, imasmiṃ kāyasmiṃ vividhā vedanā uppajjanti, sukhāpi vedanā uppajjati, dukkhāpi vedanā uppajjati, adukkhamasukhāpi vedanā uppajjatī”ti.
sn36.13:1.3.eng: In the same way, various feelings arise in this body: pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings.”

sn36.14:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, āgantukāgāraṃ. Tattha puratthimāyapi disāya āgantvā vāsaṃ kappenti, pacchimāyapi disāya āgantvā vāsaṃ kappenti, uttarāyapi disāya āgantvā vāsaṃ kappenti, dakkhiṇāyapi disāya āgantvā vāsaṃ kappenti. Khattiyāpi āgantvā vāsaṃ kappenti, brāhmaṇāpi āgantvā vāsaṃ kappenti, vessāpi āgantvā vāsaṃ kappenti, suddāpi āgantvā vāsaṃ kappenti.
sn36.14:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose there was a guest house. Lodgers come from the east, west, north, and south. Aristocrats, brahmins, peasants, and menials all stay there.

sn36.14:1.2.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, imasmiṃ kāyasmiṃ vividhā vedanā uppajjanti. Sukhāpi vedanā uppajjati, dukkhāpi vedanā uppajjati, adukkhamasukhāpi vedanā uppajjati.
sn36.14:1.2.eng: In the same way, various feelings arise in this body: pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings.

sn36.14:1.3.pli: Sāmisāpi sukhā vedanā uppajjati, sāmisāpi dukkhā vedanā uppajjati, sāmisāpi adukkhamasukhā vedanā uppajjati.
sn36.14:1.3.eng: Also pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings of the flesh arise.

sn36.14:1.4.pli: Nirāmisāpi sukhā vedanā uppajjati, nirāmisāpi dukkhā vedanā uppajjati, nirāmisāpi adukkhamasukhā vedanā uppajjatī”ti.
sn36.14:1.4.eng: Also pleasant, painful, and neutral feelings not of the flesh arise.”

sn36.15:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi, ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn36.15:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha … sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn36.15:1.2.pli: “katamā nu kho, bhante, vedanā, katamo vedanāsamudayo, katamo vedanānirodho, katamā vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā?
sn36.15:1.2.eng: “Sir, what is feeling? What’s the origin of feeling? What’s the cessation of feeling? What’s the practice that leads to the cessation of feeling?

sn36.15:1.3.pli: Ko vedanāya assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇan”ti?
sn36.15:1.3.eng: And what is feeling’s gratification, drawback, and escape?”

sn36.15:1.5.pli: sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—

sn36.15:1.9.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
sn36.15:1.9.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of feelings is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn36.15:1.10.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn36.15:1.11.pli: Yaṃ vedanaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, ayaṃ vedanāya assādo.
sn36.15:1.11.eng: The pleasure and happiness that arise from feeling: this is its gratification.

sn36.15:1.12.pli: Yaṃ vedanā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā, ayaṃ vedanāya ādīnavo.
sn36.15:1.12.eng: That feeling is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.

sn36.15:1.13.pli: Yo vedanāya chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ, idaṃ vedanāya nissaraṇaṃ.
sn36.15:1.13.eng: Removing and giving up desire and greed for feeling: this is its escape.

sn36.15:1.14.pli: Atha kho panānanda, mayā anupubbasaṅkhārānaṃ nirodho akkhāto.
sn36.15:1.14.eng: But I have also explained the progressive cessation of activities.

sn36.15:1.15.pli: Paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa vācā niruddhā hoti …pe…
sn36.15:1.15.eng: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has ceased. …

sn36.15:1.16.pli: saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpannassa saññā ca vedanā ca niruddhā honti.
sn36.15:1.16.eng: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have ceased.

sn36.15:1.17.pli: Khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno rāgo niruddho hoti, doso niruddho hoti, moho niruddho hoti.
sn36.15:1.17.eng: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have ceased.

sn36.15:1.18.pli: Atha kho panānanda, mayā anupubbasaṅkhārānaṃ vūpasamo akkhāto.
sn36.15:1.18.eng: And I have also explained the progressive settling of activities.

sn36.15:1.19.pli: Paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa vācā vūpasantā hoti …pe…
sn36.15:1.19.eng: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has stilled. …

sn36.15:1.20.pli: saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpannassa saññā ca vedanā ca vūpasantā honti.
sn36.15:1.20.eng: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have stilled.

sn36.15:1.21.pli: Khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno rāgo vūpasanto hoti, doso vūpasanto hoti, moho vūpasanto hoti.
sn36.15:1.21.eng: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have stilled.

sn36.15:1.22.pli: Atha kho panānanda, mayā anupubbasaṅkhārānaṃ paṭippassaddhi akkhātā.
sn36.15:1.22.eng: And I have also explained the progressive tranquilizing of activities.

sn36.15:1.23.pli: Paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa vācā paṭippassaddhā hoti …pe…
sn36.15:1.23.eng: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has been tranquilized. …

sn36.15:1.24.eng: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite space, the perception of form has been tranquilized.

sn36.15:1.25.eng: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite consciousness, the perception of the dimension of infinite space has been tranquilized.

sn36.15:1.26.eng: For someone who has attained the dimension of nothingness, the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness has been tranquilized.

sn36.15:1.27.eng: For someone who has attained the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, the perception of the dimension of nothingness has been tranquilized.

sn36.15:1.28.pli: Saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpannassa saññā ca vedanā ca paṭippassaddhā honti.
sn36.15:1.28.eng: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have been tranquilized.

sn36.15:1.29.pli: Khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno rāgo paṭippassaddho hoti, doso paṭippassaddho hoti, moho paṭippassaddho hotī”ti.
sn36.15:1.29.eng: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have been tranquilized.”

sn36.16:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn36.16:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,

sn36.16:1.2.pli: “katamā nu kho, ānanda, vedanā, katamo vedanāsamudayo, katamo vedanānirodho, katamā vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā?
sn36.16:1.2.eng: “Ānanda, what is feeling? What’s the origin of feeling? What’s the cessation of feeling? What’s the practice that leads to the cessation of feeling?

sn36.16:1.3.pli: Ko vedanāya assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇan”ti?
sn36.16:1.3.eng: And what is feeling’s gratification, drawback, and escape?”

sn36.16:1.4.pli: “Bhagavaṃmūlakā no, bhante, dhammā bhagavaṃnettikā bhagavaṃpaṭisaraṇā. Sādhu, bhante, bhagavantaññeva paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
sn36.16:1.4.eng: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

sn36.16:1.5.pli: “Tena hi, ānanda, suṇohi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
sn36.16:1.5.eng: “Well then, Ānanda, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

sn36.16:1.6.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

sn36.16:1.9.pli: sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—

sn36.16:1.12.pli: khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno rāgo paṭippassaddho hoti, doso paṭippassaddho hoti, moho paṭippassaddho hotī”ti.
sn36.16:1.12.eng: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have been tranquilized.”

sn36.17:1.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn36.17:1.1.eng: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn36.17:1.2.pli: “katamā nu kho, bhante, vedanā, katamo vedanāsamudayo, katamo vedanānirodho, katamā vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā?
sn36.17:1.2.eng: “Sir, what is feeling? What’s the origin of feeling? What’s the cessation of feeling? What’s the practice that leads to the cessation of feeling?

sn36.17:1.3.pli: Ko vedanāya assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇan”ti?
sn36.17:1.3.eng: And what is feeling’s gratification, drawback, and escape?”

sn36.17:1.5.pli: sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—

sn36.17:1.9.pli: Ayameva ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo vedanānirodhagāminī paṭipadā, seyyathidaṃ—
sn36.17:1.9.eng: The practice that leads to the cessation of feelings is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn36.17:1.10.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn36.17:1.11.pli: Yaṃ vedanaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, ayaṃ vedanāya assādo.
sn36.17:1.11.eng: The pleasure and happiness that arise from feeling: this is its gratification.

sn36.17:1.12.pli: Yaṃ vedanā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā, ayaṃ vedanāya ādīnavo.
sn36.17:1.12.eng: That feeling is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.

sn36.17:1.13.pli: Yo vedanāya chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ, idaṃ vedanāya nissaraṇaṃ.
sn36.17:1.13.eng: Removing and giving up desire and greed for feeling: this is its escape.

sn36.17:2.1.pli: Atha kho pana, bhikkhave, mayā anupubbasaṅkhārānaṃ nirodho akkhāto.
sn36.17:2.1.eng: But I have also explained the progressive cessation of activities. …

sn36.17:2.2.pli: Paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa vācā niruddhā hoti …pe…
sn36.17:2.2.eng: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has ceased. …

sn36.17:2.3.pli: khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno rāgo niruddho hoti, doso niruddho hoti, moho niruddho hoti.
sn36.17:2.3.eng: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have ceased.

sn36.17:2.4.pli: Atha kho pana, bhikkhave, mayā anupubbasaṅkhārānaṃ vūpasamo akkhāto.
sn36.17:2.4.eng: And I have also explained the progressive settling of activities.

sn36.17:2.5.pli: Paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa vācā vūpasantā hoti …pe…
sn36.17:2.5.eng: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has stilled. …

sn36.17:2.6.pli: khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno rāgo vūpasanto hoti, doso vūpasanto hoti, moho vūpasanto hoti.
sn36.17:2.6.eng: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have stilled.

sn36.17:2.7.eng: There are these six levels of tranquility.

sn36.17:2.8.pli: Paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa vācā paṭippassaddhā hoti.
sn36.17:2.8.eng: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has been tranquilized.

sn36.17:2.9.pli: Dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa vitakkavicārā paṭippassaddhā honti.
sn36.17:2.9.eng: For someone who has attained the second absorption, the placing of the mind and keeping it connected have been tranquilized.

sn36.17:2.10.pli: Tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa pīti paṭippassaddhā hoti.
sn36.17:2.10.eng: For someone who has attained the third absorption, rapture has been tranquilized.

sn36.17:2.11.pli: Catutthaṃ jhānaṃ samāpannassa assāsapassāsā paṭippassaddhā honti.
sn36.17:2.11.eng: For someone who has attained the fourth absorption, breathing has been tranquilized.

sn36.17:2.12.pli: Saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpannassa saññā ca vedanā ca paṭippassaddhā honti.
sn36.17:2.12.eng: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have been tranquilized.

sn36.17:2.13.pli: Khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno rāgo paṭippassaddho hoti, doso paṭippassaddho hoti, moho paṭippassaddho hotī”ti.
sn36.17:2.13.eng: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have been tranquilized.”
